'''Martha Copeland''' was an [[United States|American]] [[classic female blues]] [[singing|singer]], who recorded 34 songs between 1923 and 1928. Her best known offerings are "Everybody Does It Now," "Good Time Mama Blues" and "Sorrow Valley Blues." Promoted by [[Columbia Records]] as 'Everybody's Mammy',<ref>Stewart-Baxter, Derrick, 1970. ''Ma Rainey  and the classic blues singers''. London: Studio Vista. {{OCLC|250212516}} p. 77.</ref> her [[sound recording and reproduction|recordings]] did not sell in the quantities enjoyed by her [[record label|label mates]] [[Bessie Smith|Bessie]] and [[Clara Smith]].<ref name="Oldies">{{cite web|url=http://www.oldies.com/artist-biography/Martha-Copeland-Irene-Scruggs.html |title=Martha Copeland / Irene Scruggs Biography |publisher=Oldies.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}}</ref> Outside of her recording career, little is known of her life.<ref name="Red hot"/>

==Biography==
Copeland's birth date is unknown, although [[Paul Oliver]] in his [[record sleeve]] notes to ''The Story of The Blues, Vol. 2'', commented that she was in her forties when [[Victoria Spivey]] (born 1906) was in her [[adolescence|teens]].<ref>Album notes to ''The Story of The Blues, Vol. 2'' - supporting Oliver's book, ''The Story of The Blues'', published by Barrie and Rockliff, The Cresset Press</ref>  Copeland started her recording career with [[Okeh Records|Okeh]] in 1923, and appeared in a [[vaudeville]] [[revue]], ''Shuffle Along''. Her output veered between [[List of blues standards|blues standard]]s; mirror images of current popular tracks ("Soul and Body," in response to [[Coleman Hawkins]]'s, "[[Body and Soul (song)|Body and Soul]]"); and [[comedy|comedic]] numbers ("I Ain't Your Hen, Mr. Fly Rooster" and "When The Wind Make Connection With Your Dry Goods").<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|author=Eugene Chadbourne |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/martha-copeland-mn0000365846/biography |title=Martha Copeland | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}}</ref>

Her more notable accompanists at various recordings included [[Rube Bloom]], [[Eddie Heywood]], [[Lou Hooper]], [[Cliff Jackson]], [[James P. Johnson]], and [[Louis Metcalf]] (all on [[piano]]), plus [[Bob Fuller]] ([[clarinet]]), and [[James "Bubber" Miley|Bubber Miley]] ([[trumpet]]).<ref name="Red hot">{{cite web|url=http://www.redhotjazz.com/copeland.html |title=Martha Copeland |publisher=Redhotjazz.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}}</ref>

Her total recording output is available on ''Complete Recorded Works, Vol. 1 (1923-1927),'' and ''Complete Recorded Works, Vol. 2 (1927-1928)'' ([[Document Records|Document]]).<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/martha-copeland-mn0000365846/discography |title=Martha Copeland | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1995-11-21 |accessdate=2014-01-27}}</ref> Various [[compilation album]]s also contain examples of Copeland's work.<ref name="AMG"/>
